list.name: Changes
list.comment:
Human MOtion -> Data Preparation -- create merge-features section to merge high-frequency feature sets with SpeedAcc feature set -- define which features should be used for hypothesis-driven approach WIP
-- did probably more which I dont remember

component.name: FlaskConsoleOptions
component.custom-start-script: import sys sys.path.extend([WORKING_DIR_AND_PYTHON_PATHS]) from flask.cli import ScriptInfo locals().update(ScriptInfo(create_app=None).load_app().make_shell_context()) print("Python %s on %s\nApp: %s [%s]\nInstance: %s" % (sys.version, sys.platform, app.import_name, app.env, app.instance_path))

option.name: myCustomStartScript
option.value: import sys sys.path.extend([WORKING_DIR_AND_PYTHON_PATHS]) from flask.cli import ScriptInfo locals().update(ScriptInfo(create_app=None).load_app().make_shell_context()) print("Python %s on %s\nApp: %s [%s]\nInstance: %s" % (sys.version, sys.platform, app.import_name, app.env, app.instance_path))

restructured the folder & files
restructured the folder & files

restructured the folder & files; created new branch

added requirements.txt
worked on GPS_clustering: updated the functions regarding the identification of most frequent locations via clustering
worked on GPS_clustering: updated the functions regarding the identification of most frequent locations via clustering
worked on GPS_clustering: updated the functions regarding the identification of most frequent locations via clustering
worked on GPS_clustering: updated the functions regarding the identification of most frequent locations via clustering

- initial_transofrms_class --> created method to merge participant IDs
- main --> human motion: created summary of the label classes per participant --> adapted analysis to focus on stationary human motion

location model - merged participant IDs - transformed location labels so they conform with the classified ones (from the frequent locations) - selected for every event one location - computed classifications for these locations (and also second-best classification; both including distance to the event location) - computed classification accuracy

public transport model - create DF for public transport based on the GPS features --> output: balanced accuracy: around 54%
before and after sleep model - created specific features for this model --> GPS features --> times: hour of day and day of week --> human motion model output --> locations model output - trained decision forest on it --> balanced accuracy: 54%

public transport model - create DF for public transport based on the GPS features --> output: balanced accuracy: around 54%
before and after sleep model - created specific features for this model --> GPS features --> times: hour of day and day of week --> human motion model output --> locations model output - trained decision forest on it --> balanced accuracy: 54%

Include iteration 02 label information -> create user database: user names & user IDs (not yet included) and new user IDs -> create label dictionaries with information of the activity times for every user

Label Iteration 02 SensorData --> label all sensordata from iteration 02 --> delete sensordata which has no labels
Interesting Insight: a lot of location (=GPS) data is missing unfortunately :(

Three Tasks accomplished: 1. merge sensordata of same participant --> this was necessary for sensordata of Benedikt as he had several times saved his sensordata
2. Add ESM_timestamps --> the labeled sensordata was segmented into "ESM events" of 90 seconds length (= ESM_timestamp column added) --> this is necessary to be able to easily reuse all functions from the iteration 01 code
3. Merge sensordata of different participants of same sensors --> after this step we now have for every sensor one sensorfile include all the labeled and ESM_timestamped sensordata from all participants

Implement feature extraction for high-frequency sensors using tsfresh --> feature extraction code adapted so that feature segments are calculated based on timestamps (and not based on sampling rate anymore) --> features extracted for every sensor separately in chunks: the sensordata of every sensor is taken from the merged sensorfile which contains data of all highfrequency sensors (Note: no data was lost while merging due to improved code). Calculating features this way for every sensor separately is better than calculating it for all highfrequency sensors together as no data is lost (when calculating it for all sensors together, only rows with no missing values are considered, therefore losing any entry where in any sensor there is a missing value) --> chunks have been combined per sensor
Left to do: combining the features extracted from different sensors

Implement feature extraction for high-frequency sensors using tsfresh - Part 2 --> remaining part of combining the features extracted from different sensors into one file (so there is one file for each sensor_segment of 1,2,5,10, and 30 seconds now) implemented. Note: it is important to merge the different sensor-feature-files based on timestamp AND device_id, as for two users there are the same timestamps (and also ESM_timestamps)!

Adaptions: create dict_esmtimestamp-label which maps the ESM_timestamps to the label_human motion - general labels. This is needed in order to be able to use the feature selection function from iteration 01.
ADDITIONALLY, discovered and solved an error in the labeling of the sensor data: the initial label information was stored in dictionary (one for every participant) with the keys being the activities. If one participant collected two times the same activiy, the first activity information was overriten. This problem is now solved.
Note: it took SOO much longer than expected...

Data-driven feature selection (using, unter anderem, tsfresh feature selection algorithms) for high-frequency features implemented --> in order to implement, needed to create dictionary which maps ESM_timestamp to labels (in order to be able to label the features-extracted before feature selection) -> this was done in previous commit
Modeling: create Decision Forest based on all features from high-frequency sensors (features selected in data driven way)
Transportation Mode -> Data Exploration -> did a lot of things, don´t remember exactly what

Active Smartphone Session: Create Sensor Data which only contains sensor data for the active smartphone session around each event - did that - calculated the GPS features speed and acceleration based on this new sensor data - calculated the summary statistics based on this new sensor data

General Data Preparation -> GPS Speed & Acceleration Calculation -- adapted the algorithm for calculating acceleration so that it calculates now km/h per second. The algorithm before claimed to calculate m/s^2, but actually something was wrong in the formula

Human MOtion -> Data Preparation -- create merge-features section to merge high-frequency feature sets with SpeedAcc feature set -- define which features should be used for hypothesis-driven approach WIP
-- did probably more which I dont remember

MESSAGE.value: This is the first commit message
restructured the folder & files
restructured the folder & files; created new branch
added requirements.txt
worked on GPS_clustering: updated the functions regarding the identification of most frequent locations via clustering

- initial_transofrms_class --> created method to merge participant IDs
- main --> human motion: created summary of the label classes per participant --> adapted analysis to focus on stationary human motion

location model - merged participant IDs - transformed location labels so they conform with the classified ones (from the frequent locations) - selected for every event one location - computed classifications for these locations (and also second-best classification; both including distance to the event location) - computed classification accuracy

public transport model - create DF for public transport based on the GPS features --> output: balanced accuracy: around 54%
before and after sleep model - created specific features for this model --> GPS features --> times: hour of day and day of week --> human motion model output --> locations model output - trained decision forest on it --> balanced accuracy: 54%

Include iteration 02 label information -> create user database: user names & user IDs (not yet included) and new user IDs -> create label dictionaries with information of the activity times for every user

Label Iteration 02 SensorData --> label all sensordata from iteration 02 --> delete sensordata which has no labels
Interesting Insight: a lot of location (=GPS) data is missing unfortunately :(

Three Tasks accomplished: 1. merge sensordata of same participant --> this was necessary for sensordata of Benedikt as he had several times saved his sensordata
2. Add ESM_timestamps --> the labeled sensordata was segmented into "ESM events" of 90 seconds length (= ESM_timestamp column added) --> this is necessary to be able to easily reuse all functions from the iteration 01 code
3. Merge sensordata of different participants of same sensors --> after this step we now have for every sensor one sensorfile include all the labeled and ESM_timestamped sensordata from all participants

Implement feature extraction for high-frequency sensors using tsfresh --> feature extraction code adapted so that feature segments are calculated based on timestamps (and not based on sampling rate anymore) --> features extracted for every sensor separately in chunks: the sensordata of every sensor is taken from the merged sensorfile which contains data of all highfrequency sensors (Note: no data was lost while merging due to improved code). Calculating features this way for every sensor separately is better than calculating it for all highfrequency sensors together as no data is lost (when calculating it for all sensors together, only rows with no missing values are considered, therefore losing any entry where in any sensor there is a missing value) --> chunks have been combined per sensor
Left to do: combining the features extracted from different sensors

Implement feature extraction for high-frequency sensors using tsfresh - Part 2 --> remaining part of combining the features extracted from different sensors into one file (so there is one file for each sensor_segment of 1,2,5,10, and 30 seconds now) implemented. Note: it is important to merge the different sensor-feature-files based on timestamp AND device_id, as for two users there are the same timestamps (and also ESM_timestamps)!

Adaptions: create dict_esmtimestamp-label which maps the ESM_timestamps to the label_human motion - general labels. This is needed in order to be able to use the feature selection function from iteration 01.
ADDITIONALLY, discovered and solved an error in the labeling of the sensor data: the initial label information was stored in dictionary (one for every participant) with the keys being the activities. If one participant collected two times the same activiy, the first activity information was overriten. This problem is now solved.
Note: it took SOO much longer than expected...

Data-driven feature selection (using, unter anderem, tsfresh feature selection algorithms) for high-frequency features implemented --> in order to implement, needed to create dictionary which maps ESM_timestamp to labels (in order to be able to label the features-extracted before feature selection) -> this was done in previous commit
Modeling: create Decision Forest based on all features from high-frequency sensors (features selected in data driven way)
Transportation Mode -> Data Exploration -> did a lot of things, don´t remember exactly what

Active Smartphone Session: Create Sensor Data which only contains sensor data for the active smartphone session around each event - did that - calculated the GPS features speed and acceleration based on this new sensor data - calculated the summary statistics based on this new sensor data

General Data Preparation -> GPS Speed & Acceleration Calculation -- adapted the algorithm for calculating acceleration so that it calculates now km/h per second. The algorithm before claimed to calculate m/s^2, but actually something was wrong in the formula

Human MOtion -> Data Preparation -- create merge-features section to merge high-frequency feature sets with SpeedAcc feature set -- define which features should be used for hypothesis-driven approach WIP
-- did probably more which I dont remember
